Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing Brittle Failure and Fracture Propagation in Fast Ice Sliding with Dynamic Rupture Models based on Whillans Ice Stream Seismic/Geodetic Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates a rapidly moving section of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet known as the Whillans Ice Stream. Ice streams and outlet glaciers are the major pathways for ice discharge from ice sheets into the ocean. Consequently, understanding ice stream dynamics, specifically the processes controlling the frictional resistance of ice sliding on sediments at its base, is essential for predictive modeling of how Earth's ice sheets will respond to a changing climate. Rather than flowing smoothly, Whillans Ice Stream advances in stick-slip cycles: brief periods of rapid sliding, equivalent to magnitude 7 earthquakes, alternating with much longer periods of repose. The PIs will perform simulations of these stick-slip cycles using computer codes originally developed for modeling tectonic earthquakes. By matching observed ice motions, the PIs will constrain the range of frictional processes acting at the base of the ice stream. An additional focus of the project is on brittle fracture processes in ice, expressed through seismic waves radiated by faulting and/or crevassing episodes that accompany the large-scale sliding events. An understanding of ice fracture provides a basis for assessing the susceptibility of ice shelves to rifting and catastrophic disintegration. Project results will be incorporated into outreach activities (from elementary school to community college events) as well as a polar science class for the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (COSMOS) program for high school students.

Simulations of the stick-slip cycle will employ 3D dynamic rupture models that simultaneously solve for the seismic wavefield and rupture process, consistent with elastodynamic material response and friction laws on the ice stream bed. Stresses and frictional properties will be varied to achieve consistency with surface GPS and broadband seismic data as well as borehole seismograms from the WISSARD project. The results will be interpreted using laboratory till friction experiments, which link velocity-weakening/strengthening behavior to temperature and water content, and to related experiments quantifying basal drag from ice flow over rough beds. The source mechanism of seismicity accompanying the slip events (shear faulting versus crevassing) will be determined using 3D waveform modeling in conjunction with mechanical models of the seismic source processes. This proposal does not require fieldwork in the Antarctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much of the ice from the Antarctic Ice Sheet flows to the coast through fast-flowing ice streams. How fast these ice streams flow depends on the frictional resistance at the bottom of the ice stream, where it rests on a layer of glacial till (similar to clay). One project objective was to characterize friction beneath the Whillans Ice Stream (WIS) in West Antarctica. The WIS is unique in that instead of sliding continuously to the coast, it instead advances through intermittent earthquake-like slip events that happen twice daily, with relatively little sliding happening at other times (stick phase). This project transferred the current theoretical understanding of earthquake stick-slip cycles, and associated computer simulation tools, to the field of glaciology. Simulations were performed to match observed features of the WIS stick-slip cycles, such as how often the slip events occur, how they are synchronized with the ocean tides, how much slip occurs during each event, etc. Certain parameters in the friction law, such as the water pressure beneath the ice stream, were varied to fit available data (specifically, GPS measurements of ice surface motion). Ice streams are changing features over decadal time scales, and nearby ice streams that were active in the past centuries are now inactive. The simulations make testable predictions about how the WIS stick-slip cycles will respond to changes in water pressure, which is a leading hypothesis for why other ice streams have shut off. This might be useful because water pressure is impossible to measure directly (without expensive drilling), but observations of how frequently the WIS slip events occur, how large they are, etc., are much easier to obtain from GPS data – and work in this project has quantified how these characteristics change as water pressure changes. 

A second project effort explored seismic tremor that occurs during WIS slip events. Seismic tremors are vibrations of the ice stream detected with seismometers on the ice surface. They were hypothesized to be caused by rapidly repeating small earthquakes (at a rate of up to ten or more events per second) at the bottom of the WIS. It is thought that small patches, likely just a few meters across, are more resistant to sliding, and that these patches advance in an oscillatory, stick-slip manner during the large-scale sliding of the WIS. Computer simulations, based on well-established ideas from earthquake physics, were used to test this hypothesis. The seismic observations were matched by the simulations by varying patch size and frictional properties, again placing constraints on these parameters. These constraints provide quantitative insights into the nature of friction at the bottom of the ice stream.

Results from these studies can be used by the broader glaciology community to help select and calibrate ice stream frictional sliding laws for use in ice sheet evolution simulations.

The project provided training for two PhD students at Stanford University.
